Hiring Alert!Fullstack Developer (C#, Javascript / JS Frameworks)📍Bengaluru, Karnataka🕒 Full Time, 5 Days/WeekExperience required - 3-10 yearsRole & ResponsibilitiesAbout the Role:We are seeking a talented and motivated Full Stack Developer to join our dynamic Apra labs team. The ideal candidate will have hands-on experience across a variety of front-end, back-end, and database technologies. This role involves working with modern web frameworks, creating and consuming REST APIs, and working on data-driven solutions using the latest cloud technologies and reporting 🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

🧠 Action vs Func vs Predicate in C# ▶️ Think of them as different types of hired helpers:🛠️ Action — “Do something, don’t return anything”Like hiring someone to clean your room. You don’t expect a report — just get it done.Action<string> sayHi = name => Console.WriteLine($"Hi, {name}!");sayHi("Benito");🧼 It performs a task but returns nothing (void).🔍 Func — “Do something and give me a result”Like hiring someone to calculate your taxes. You give them info, they give you a number.Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;int sum = add(3, 5); 📦 It always returns a value  the last generic type is the return type.✅ Predicate — “Check a condition and return true/false”Like asking: “Is this email spam?” You get a yes/no answer — that’s it.Predicate<int> isEven = num => num % 2 == 0;bool result = isEven(4); // true✅ It always returns a bool.hashtag#CSharp hashtag#DotNet hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#Func hashtag#Action hashtag#Predicate hashtag#Delegates hashtag#DevTips hashtag#SoftwareEngineering
